sn36.12:1.1: “Mendicants, various winds blow in the sky.
sn36.12:1.2: Winds blow from the east, the west, the north, and the south. There are winds that are dusty and dustless, cool and warm, weak and strong.
sn36.12:1.3: In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.
sn36.12:2.2: winds that blow in the sky.
sn36.12:2.3: From the east they come, also the west,
sn36.12:2.4: the north, and then the south.
sn36.12:3.4: these are the different breezes that blow.
sn36.12:5.1: But when a mendicant is keen,
sn36.12:6.2: they’re without defilements in this very life.
sn36.12:6.3: That knowledge master is firm in principle;
sn36.12:6.4: when their body breaks up, they can’t be reckoned.”
